Farmers can certainly improve the quality of their soil through fertilization and other methods, although the extent to which they can do so depends on the natural properties of the soil.

Fertilization is one of the most common methods used to improve soil quality. By adding nutrients to the soil, farmers can improve the fertility of the soil and increase crop yields. However, it is important for farmers to carefully manage the type and amount of fertilizer they use, as over-application can lead to soil degradation, water pollution, and other problems.

Another method for improving soil quality is through soil conservation techniques, such as cover cropping, crop rotation, and reduced tillage. These practices can help to reduce erosion, improve soil structure, and increase the amount of organic matter in the soil.

In some cases, farmers may also be able to alter the physical or chemical properties of the soil through land reclamation techniques. For example, in areas where the soil has been degraded by mining or other activities, farmers may be able to restore the soil by adding organic matter, limestone, or other soil amendments.

Overall, while farmers may be able to improve the quality of their soil to some extent through fertilization and other methods, they are ultimately limited by the natural properties of the soil. In areas where the soil is highly degraded or unsuitable for agriculture, it may be necessary to explore alternate land uses, such as agroforestry, or to implement more extensive land reclamation strategies.
